metadata.title: Phoneme discrimination using KS-algebra I

sections.text: In our thesis we define a new algebra of operators as a replacement for fuzzy logic. Its main purpose is the construction of binary discriminators for phonemes based on spectral content. It is optimized for the design of non-parametric computational circuits and uses 4 operations: min, max, difference and generalized additive homogeneous means.

From a physical point of view, sound is simply a vibration of air pressure, perceived by humans through a complex series of transformations. First, the vibration of air pressure is transmitted via the ear canal to the bones of the middle ear (and partially amplified by certain frequencies), transmitting vibrations in vibrations of the basil membrane, which in turn stimulate the inner hair cells. sections.heading: 5 Fuzzy logic
sections.text: The mathematical functions introduced so far (Mα, Aα and Quantile) are essentially monotonous. As spectral data increase, they also increase. To gain contrast, it is useful to have an unsymmetrical function of, say, two variables that "increase" in the first and "decrease" in the second. A well-known framework that uses such functions is fuzzy logic. Fuzzy logic goes back to works by Lukasiewicz and Post. H.
